metadata.title: MIL-101(Cr) as a synergistic catalyst for the reduction of imines with trichlorosilane

Research Paper MIL-101(Cr) as a synergistic catalyst for the reduction of imines with trichlorosilane Jingwen Chen Xiaoling Chen Zhiguo Zhang ⁎ Zongbi Bao Huabin Xing Qiwei Yang Qilong Ren Key Laboratory of Biomass Chemical Engineering of Ministry of Education, College of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Zhejiang University, Zheda Road 38, Hangzhou 310027, PR China Key Laboratory of Biomass Chemical Engineering of Ministry of Education College of Chemical and Biological Engineering Zhejiang University Zheda Road 38 Hangzhou 310027 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract MIL-101(Cr) as a synergistic catalyst for the reduction of imines with trichlorosilane as the hydrogen source was developed. The development of catalyst based on porous crystalline materials (PCM) constructed from metal ions or clusters and multidentate organic ligands is a topic of great interest. In view of the Lewis acidic and basic properties of PCMs, we report for the first time that MIL-101(Cr) works as a synergistic catalyst for the reduction of imines with trichlorosilane as the hydrogen source. Both ketimines and aldimines were tolerated with this protocol, giving the corresponding amines in moderate to high yields. The operational simplicity as well as mild reaction conditions renders this protocol an attractive approach for the synthesis of amines. Furthermore, a chiral MOF, CMIL-101, was also realized by grafting chiral N-formyl proline derivatives to the open metal sites. Moreover, CMIL-101 exhibited a comparable catalytic performance with its homogeneous counterpart in terms of yields and enantioselectivities. Keywords Metal-organic framework Reduction Imine Trichlorosilane Amine 1 Introduction Amines are ubiquitous in biologically active natural products, agrochemicals, and pharmaceuticals [1]. Hence, the development of efficient methodologies for the synthesis of these chemicals has attracted extensive interests [2,3]. Among the available approaches to amines, the reduction of CN bonds is one of most convenient methods [4,5]. The use of organometallic catalysts in conjunction with hydrogen gas represents a powerful and widely used method for the production of amines, even on industrial scale [6,7]. To avoid the potential risk in manipulating the high pressure hydrogen gas, isopropyl alcohol, formic acid, et al. have been demonstrated to be alternative hydrogen sources in catalytic transfer hydrogenation reactions [8–14]. Of these, trichlorosilane, a widely available by-product in the industrial Rochow process, is one of the most frequently employed stoichiometric hydrogen sources for the reduction of CO and CN functionalities [15–17]. In this context, Kobayashi and co-workers[18] found that trichlorosilane-dimethylformamide (HSiCl3-DMF) was an efficient catalytic system in the reduction of aldehydes, imines, as well as the reductive amination of aldehydes. Metal-organic frameworks are a class of porous materials, which are constructed with metal ions or clusters and organic linkers [19–22]. Because of their regular and tunable structures, MOFs-based catalysts have found wide applications in a large number of chemical transformations [23–36]. In this respect, most of catalytic activities are attributed to the coordinative unsaturated or open metal sites within MOFs. We [37] as well as others [38,39] have demonstrated that the coordinative unsaturated Cr3+ sites within MIL-101(Cr) were able to promote the cyanosilylation reaction of aldehydes efficiently. In contrast to the vast investigations of MOFs as Lewis acidic catalysts, the Lewis basicity associated with the carboxyl organic linkers in MOFs as well as their synergistic effect in catalysis has been rarely explored. In continuation of our interest in the trichlorosilane mediated reduction of imines [40], we envisaged that a MOF capable of synergistic activation of trichlorosilane and imines would serve as an efficient catalyst for this reaction. MIL-101(Cr) is constructed with chromium(III) nitrate nonahydrate and terephthalic acid, which was reported in 2005 by Férey et al. [41] It features with large pore sizes (2.9–3.4nm), high surface area, and fine chemical and thermal stability. The readily accessible coordinatively unsaturated chromium sites along with Lewis basic sites originated from the organic ligands, make MIL-101(Cr) an ideal promotor in the simultaneous activation of trichlorosilane and imine substrates. In addition, by a postsynthetic method, MIL-101(Cr) can be easily functionalized towards some specific tasks. The attachment of achiral units to the open metal sites of MIL-101(Cr) was general [42–50], however, the grafting of chiral components was less studied [51–53]. On the basis of our previous work [40], we as well as others found that N-formyl group modified Lewis bases (1, Scheme 1 ) [16,17,54–56] were efficient homogeneous catalyst for the reduction of imines. We anticipated that the immobilization of such species inside the pores of MIL-101(Cr) would possibly generate a chiral MOF for the reduction of imines with trichlorosilane, upon which the confined environment of MOFs may also benefit the enantioselectivity of the homogeneous modulators. In this work, we report that chiral MIL-101(Cr) decorated with a pyridyl modified L-proline derivative (2) acts as a chiral catalyst for asymmetric reduction of ketimines with comparable catalytic performance to its counterpart. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of catalysts 2.1.1 Preparation of metal-organic frameworks MIL-101(Cr) [41] and MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 [57] were synthesized and purified according to the method described in literature. 2.1.2 Construction of chiral MIL-101(Cr) Before post-modification, MIL-101(Cr) was activated under vacuum at 150°C for 24h to generate open metal sites. The activated MIL-101(Cr) and chiral ligand 2 (Scheme 1) was mixed together in dry chloroform, and the heterogeneous mixture was stirred, refluxed under N2 atmosphere for 24h. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature (r.t.), the solid was collected by centrifugation. After that, the resulted solid was washed thoroughly with dichloromethane and ethanol to eliminate trace amount of free organic ligand 2. The modified MOFs (denoted as CMIL-101 hereafter) was dried under vacuum before use. 2.2 General procedure for the catalytic reduction of imines with trichlorosilane All the reduction reactions of imines were performed in oven-dried Schlenk flasks. The mixture of imine 3 (0.2mmol) and the MOF catalyst in anhydrous solvent was cooled to 0°C under a nitrogen atmosphere, trichlorosilane (60μL, 0.6mmol) was added dropwise to the mixture. After the reaction completed, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation immediately, and washed with ethyl acetate for three times. The supernatant was combined and saturated solution of NaHCO3 (10mL) was added. The mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate (3×20mL). The combined organic layer was washed with brine and dried over anhydrous MgSO4, filtered and evaporated. The crude product was purified using column chromatography on silica gel eluted with a mixture of petroleum ether and ethyl acetate. 2.3 Characterization The FTIR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 400–4000cm−1. The trichlorosilane adsorbed diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) of solid catalysts were recorded on Nicolet iS50 FT-IR spectrometer. The samples were preheated in situ at 100°C for 5min and cooled to 30°C under Argon stream. The spectrum of each solid was collected and used as the blank spectrum. The sample was exposed to a trichlorosilane/Argon stream, and the time-related spectra were collected every minute during the adsorption process. Then the samples were swept by pure Argon at 30°C for 1h to examine the strength of adsorption. The spectra obtained were quantified by employing the Kubelka-Munk function. MIL-101(Cr) and CMIL-101 was degassed at 423K and 393K respectively for 12h before measuring the BET surface area on a Tri Star II Plus instrument at 77K. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a PANalytical X'Pert PRO diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation operated at 40kV, 40mA. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained using Hitachi SU-8000 instrument. Elemental analysis results were achieved on the Elementar Vario MICRO elemental analyzer. 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker Avance III device with a frequency of 400MHz. TOF MS was measured on a Waters GCT Premier Time of Flight mass spectrometer. Enantiomeric excess value of the amine products was measured on Waters equipment using Daicel Chiralpak IB column with hexane/isopropyl alcohol solvent systems. HPLC methods were calibrated with the corresponding racemic samples. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of MIL-101(Cr) MIL-101(Cr) was synthesized and purified according to the method described in literature [41]. The resulted green powder was characterized by various techniques. The SEM images in Fig. S1 demonstrated that MIL-101(Cr) was octahedron with a size around 200nm. The crystallinity of MIL-101(Cr) was confirmed by PXRD, which matches with the simulated experimental patterns of MIL-101(Cr) (Fig. S2). The surface area and pore volume of MIL-101(Cr) was determined by the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm (Fig. S3) and displayed in Table S1. The two bands at 1630 and 1398cm−1 on the IR spectrum (Fig. S4) are in agreement with the stretching vibration of carboxyl group. Thermogravimetric analysis in nitrogen (Fig. S5) revealed that MIL-101(Cr) was stable up to 275°C. 3.2 MIL-101(Cr) catalyzed reduction of imines After fully characterization of MIL-101(Cr), we next investigated its catalytic ability in the reduction of imines with trichlorosilane using N-(1-phenylethylidene)aniline (3a) as the model substrate. To illustrate the catalytic role of MIL-101(Cr), several metal salts as well as MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 were also studied (Table 1 ). NaCl (Table 1, entry 4) demonstrated a negligible catalytic effect as compared with the control experiment (Table 1, entry 1). When sodium benzoate (Table 1, entry 3) was employed as the catalyst, a slight increase of reaction rate was resulted, suggesting that benzoate is superior to chloride in activating the substrates. In the presence of catalytic amount of chromium terephthalate (Table 1, entry 2), a dramatic increase in reaction rate was observed, which may be attributed to a synergistic activation effect of Cr3+ and terephthalate. Along with this line, we are pleased to find that MIL-101(Cr) (Table 1, entry 5), consists of the same components as with chromium terephthalate, is the best catalyst for this reaction. The Cr3+ clusters and terephthalate ligands were regularly arranged inside the pores of MIL-101(Cr), which may not only functionalize synergistically in the activation of imine and trichlorosilane, but also facilitate the diffusion of substrates into the ordered pores. Therefore, an enhanced yield was observed with MIL-101(Cr) as the catalyst. The amine functionalized MIL-101(Cr) (Table 1, entry 6) was also effective for the reduction reaction, but an inferior yield was resulted. It may be caused by the decrease on BET surface area and pore volume after the introduction of amino groups into the pores of MOFs (Fig. S3 and Table S1). After MIL-101(Cr) was identified as the suitable catalyst, we further investigated the effect of catalyst amount (Table 1, entries 7–9) on the catalytic activity and found that 10mol% of catalyst loading was optimal for the reaction. With the optimized reaction conditions in hand, we next explored the generality of the reaction. All the ketimines tested bearing either with electron-withdrawing or −donating groups are applicable to this protocol, giving the corresponding amines 4a–4e in moderate to high yield (Table 2 ). Next, we focused our attention to the reduction of aldimines (Table 3 ). Interestingly, in the reduction of N-benzylidenebenzenamine (3f), moderate yield of the desired product N-benzylbenzenamine (4f) was furnished together with a tertiary amine (N,N-dibenzylaniline, 5f), which is probably formed through the reaction of product 4f with substrate 3f within the pores of MIL-101(Cr) [58]. This result with MIL-101(Cr) catalyst shows different phenomena to those catalyzed with homogeneous Lewis bases, and may in agreement with somewhat specific properties of MOFs. Then, different aldimines were used as the substrates. Generally, aldimines bearing different substituent groups were tolerated with this protocol, giving the corresponding amines 4g-4q in moderate to good yields. As observed in the reduction of 3f, the respective tertiary amine 5g-5q were always accompanied with the process except aldimine 3p, suggesting that the inherent size selectivity within the pores of MOFs was crucial for the formation of tertiary amines. Generally, the yields of products are proportional to the size of substrates, probably due to the enhanced product selectivity over tertiary amines. 3.3 Postsynthetic modification of MIL-101(Cr) Given the regular, tunable and highly porous structures, as well as the intrinsic Lewis acidity, MIL-101(Cr) was envisioned as a suitable chiral MOF precursor for the immobilization of chiral Lewis bases, allowing the convenient construction of multifunctional chiral MOF for the asymmetric catalysis. With these in mind, we further investigated the potential of MIL-101(Cr)-derived chiral MOF in the asymmetric reduction of imines. A pyridyl modified L-proline derivative (2) was used as the chiral modifier, and the chiral MIL-101(Cr) (CMIL-101) was constructed via a postsynthetic modification method, which realized by the coordination of pyridyl group of 2 with the open metal sites within MIL-101(Cr) (Scheme 2 ). As shown in Fig. 1 , the PXRD patterns of CMIL-101 was almost identical with the pristine MIL-101(Cr), indicating the retention of the parent framework structure. SEM images in Fig. 2 showed that the morphology and particle size of MIL-101(Cr) and CMIL-101 were the same. Hence, the introduction of chiral ligands didn’t change the structure of the framework. The N2 sorption and desorption isotherms of MIL-101(Cr) and CMIL-101 were showed in Fig. 3 . Due to the immobilization of bulky organic molecules inside the pores, the surface area of CMIL-101 decreased dramatically as compared with MIL-101(Cr) (Table 4 ). The successful insertion of chiral ligand was further verified by FT-IR spectrum. As showed in Fig. 4 , new peaks related with the chiral organic modulator are well observed in the range from 600cm−1 to 1800cm−1 for CMIL-101, indicating the successful entrapping of N-formyl L-proline derivative. The elemental analysis results (Table 5 ) indicated that 1.45 chiral ligands per formula were incorporated inside the pores of CMIL-101. After thorough characterization of CMIL-101, we introduced it into the catalytic reduction reaction system. The reduction of (E)-N-benzylidenebenzenamine (3a) was carried out under various solvents with chiral ligand 2 as the catalyst (Table S2). Among the solvents screened, CH2Cl2 is the most suitable one in consideration of both yield and enantioselectivity. The asymmetric reduction of imine 3a was conducted in CH2Cl2 with 2 or CMIL-101 as the catalyst. Similar yield and slightly higher ee were observed when catalyzed by CMIL-101 (Table 6 , entries 3 and 4) as compared with the free chiral organic ligand (Table 6, entries 1 and 2). Although the ee value currently is not satisfactory, we have demonstrated the feasibility of the postsynthetic modification method that converted an achiral MOF to a catalytic active chiral porous material. 3.4 Mechanistic investigation of the MIL-101(Cr) catalyzed reduction of imines To gain some insight into the catalytic mechanism of MIL-101(Cr), we employed FT-IR spectroscopic method to investigate the possible mode of action between MIL-101(Cr) and the substrates. In comparison to the FT-IR spectrum of trichlorosilane, the Si-H stretching vibration of trichlorosilane adsorbed on MIL-101(Cr) shifts to low-frequency (2259cm−1 vs 2248cm−1) (Fig. 5 ). This shift may resulted from hypervalent interaction of the abundant carboxyl group within the pores of MIL-101(Cr) with trichlorosilane [59]. When imine was mixed with MIL-101(Cr), a shift of the CN stretching vibration frequency of imine 3f to low-frequency by about 23cm−1 was also observed (Fig. 6 ). It is speculated from the coordination of unsaturated Cr3+ sites with nitrogen atom [60]. These results unambiguously demonstrated both substrates can be activated by MIL-101(Cr). For comparison, some other solid catalysts were also investigated by means of FI-IR spectroscopy and the frequency shifts were not obvious (Fig. S6-S11). In addition, the essence and strength of the interaction was further investigated by evaluating the DRIFTS of trichlorosilane adsorbed MIL-101(Cr), MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 and chromium terephthalate samples (Fig. 7 A). Upon exposure MIL-101(Cr) to the flowing gas mixture of Argon/HSiCl3, three bands at 2268, 2259 and 2251cm−1 were observed (Fig. 7 and Fig. S12). The band at 2259cm−1 is ascribed to the Si-H stretching vibration of surface adsorbed HSiCl3. The shoulder peak at 2268cm−1 is presumably originated from the trichlorosilane ligated to the surface of the catalyst, since the band disappeared quickly after initial sweeping with Argon (Fig. 7B). In contrast, the band at 2251cm−1 remained after long-time sweeping, suggesting that a strong interaction exists between MIL-101(Cr) and the adsorbed trichlorosilane molecules. When MIL-101(Cr) was replaced with MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 or chromium terephthalate (Fig. 7A and Fig. S13-S14), no obvious difference in peak position was observed at the initial adsorption process, but the adsorption intensity of IR bands decreased dramatically after sweeping with Argon, underlining the pores within MIL-101(Cr) may assist the strong interaction between MIL-101(Cr) and trichlorosilane and subsequent activation. Furthermore, the negative peak at 3673cm−1 possibly due to the interaction between trichlorosialne molecules and hydroxyl groups (CrOH) within MOF to form H-bonded complexes. Such phenomena were not observed in trichlorosilane adsorbed chromium terephthalate, indicating a weaker interaction between trichlorosilane and chromium terephthalate as compared with that of MOFs samples. The mechanistic investigations using IR experiments suggests that the superior performance of MIL-101(Cr) to its congeners is in close relationship with its regular structure, large pore size as well as a synergistic activation mode on nodes. 4 Conclusions In summary, the chemically and thermally robust MIL-101(Cr) was prepared easily via a hydrothermal reaction of chromium(III) nitrate nonahydrate and terephthalic acid. It shows good catalytic activity for the reduction of imines with trichlorosilane as the hydrogen source. This method represents the first example of MOFs catalyzed reduction of CN bonds with trichlorosilane and gives the corresponding amines in moderate to good yields. Furthermore, in contrast to homogeneous Lewis base catalysts, the formation of tertiary amines was always accompanied with the reduction of aldimines, which shows clearly size-selectivity in line with MOFs catalysts. Besides, chiral MOF was achieved by postsynthetic modification, with a pyridyl group coordinate to the open metal sites of MIL-101(Cr). As compared with the free chiral modifier, similar yield and slightly higher ee value of the hydrogenated product were achieved when catalyzed by CMIL-101. Mechanistic investigation using FT-IR and DRIFT spectroscopy demonstrates that the porous structures of MIL-101(Cr) enhances the synergistic interaction of substrates with catalyst and accordingly contributes to its high catalytic performance. Future research will be directed toward the careful construction of chiral MOFs for asymmetric catalytic reactions. coredata.dc:description: The development of catalyst based on porous crystalline materials (PCM) constructed from metal ions or clusters and multidentate organic ligands is a topic of great interest. In view of the Lewis acidic and basic properties of PCMs, we report for the first time that MIL-101(Cr) works as a synergistic catalyst for the reduction of imines with trichlorosilane as the hydrogen source. Both ketimines and aldimines were tolerated with this protocol, giving the corresponding amines in moderate to high yields. The operational simplicity as well as mild reaction conditions renders this protocol an attractive approach for the synthesis of amines. Furthermore, a chiral MOF, CMIL-101, was also realized by grafting chiral N-formyl proline derivatives to the open metal sites. Moreover, CMIL-101 exhibited a comparable catalytic performance with its homogeneous counterpart in terms of yields and enantioselectivities.
coredata.dc:title: MIL-101(Cr) as a synergistic catalyst for the reduction of imines with trichlorosilane
